newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia rejects U.S. pressure over religion law.
newsitem.headline: Russia rejects U.S. pressure over religion law.

text.p: Russia said on Friday that U.S. Senate pressure on President Boris Yeltsin not to sign a controversial bill curbing the rights of minority religions is premature and counter-productive.

The Russian Foreign Ministry issued a statement saying the bill "On Freedom of Conscience and Religious Association" would be signed into law by Yeltsin only after legal experts had ruled whether it tallied with the constitution and human rights standards.

"The reaction by the American senators to the law, which has not come into force yet, causes nothing but surprise," the ministry said. "It should have been clear that all types of conditions are counter-productive."

The U.S. Senate voted earlier this week to cut off aid to Russia if Yeltsin signed the bill, which would give a few major confessions such as Orthodoxy, Islam, Judaism and mainstream Buddhism big advantages over minority religions.
The threatened curb on new assistance was approved as an amendment to a $13.2 billion foreign aid bill now moving through the Senate. The measure contains about $200 million in funds for Russia.

Under the new Russian legislation, only religions which have operated in the country for more than 15 years can set up new religious organisations. This gives a built-in advantage to traditional confessions active in Russia during the Soviet era.
The Foreign Ministry said similar protectionism was practised by some other states and argued that Russia had to counter "totalitarian sects and pseudo-religious groups".

The law, hotly defended by the Orthodox Church and communist opposition, was criticised by Pope John Paul on Thursday. He told Yeltsin in a letter released by the Vatican that the bill threatened the survival of the Roman Catholic Church in Russia.
The Foreign Ministry statement did not refer to the Pope's criticism.
Parliament approved the bill earlier this month and Yeltsin can either sign it now or veto it, but his veto could be overruled by a two-thirds majority in each chamber.
